summary: Respiratory infections in the cystic fibrosis lung remain the primary cause of mortality and morbidity in CF. the defective function of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator gene initiates a lifelong cycle of neutrophilic inflammation, progressive bronchiectasis, mucus obstruction and recurrent microbial infection of the CF airway. the CF airway environment is vulnerable to colonization by particular bacterial and fungi RV is the most common respiratory virus detected in CF airway. despite numerous studies into the virology of CF airways, the mechanistic link between virus infection, airway inflammation and structural lung disease remains unknown. there are more than 150 serotypes of RV, which have been classified into 3 species; RV-A, RV-B, and RV-C. the cell receptor for RV-C species has been identified as cadherin related family member 3. RV load has been observed to be significantly higher in children with CF (>100 times) when compared to healthy controls. an age preference for RV-associated CF exacerbations has also been reported for young children 5 years old. RV infection in adults is accompanied by an increased risk of PEx, prolonged antibiotic prescription, higher respiratory symptom scores and heightened level of C-reactive protein. it is critical to elucidate how this virus alters host antiviral and inflammatory responses.
